title: Solar Wind Compressibility
subtitle: How density fluctuations regulate helium
description: Hydrogen compressibility (density fluctuations) is the primary regulator of helium abundance saturation in the solar wind. When compressibility drops below 9%, helium saturates at a universal value regardless of speed or Alfvenicity. This incompressibility threshold provides a powerful diagnostic for identifying solar wind source regions.

primary_figure.short_title: Compressibility Maps Show Saturation in Incompressible Wind
primary_figure.alt: A heat map showing compressibility versus solar wind speed and helium abundance, revealing saturation occurs exclusively in incompressible wind

summary.what_we_see: This heat map displays compressibility as color across the helium abundance (0-10%) versus solar wind speed (300-800 km/s) plane. Deep blue indicates incompressible wind where density barely fluctuates, yellow shows moderate fluctuations, and orange-red marks compressible wind with substantial density variations. A striking diagonal divide separates the blue incompressible lower-left region from the orange compressible upper-right.
summary.the_finding: Helium saturation occurs exclusively in incompressible solar wind where density fluctuations remain below 9%. All saturation points sit firmly in the blue incompressible region, avoiding compressible areas entirely. This resolves the crossover puzzle from Alfvenicity-based analysis: non-Alfvenic wind at 530-560 km/s reaches the edge of the incompressible regime where compressibility begins enhancing helium, while Alfvenic wind remains deep in the incompressible zone.
summary.why_it_matters: Compressibility, not Alfvenicity, is the primary regulator of helium saturation. Coronal holes produce saturated wind not because they are Alfvenic, but because their open-field topology suppresses compressive fluctuations below 9%. This provides a practical classification threshold: density fluctuations below 9% indicate coronal-hole-type wind regardless of wave coherence, enabling reliable source region identification from in situ measurements.

related_figures.alt: Multi-curve plot showing helium abundance versus speed for 15 compressibility levels
related_figures.relevance: Shows universal saturation below 15% compressibility threshold
related_figures.summary_short: All 12 incompressible quantiles (density fluctuations below 15%) saturate at indistinguishable speeds and abundances. The saturation mechanism is remarkably robust: as long as compressibility stays below 15%, the exact level barely matters. Compressible wind shows no saturation, continuing to climb steeply.

related_figures.alt: Four-panel contour maps showing helium statistics across cross helicity and compressibility space
related_figures.relevance: Reveals dual role of compressibility in mean abundance vs variability
related_figures.summary_short: Compressibility plays a dual, paradoxical role: Alfvenic wind (low compressibility, high cross helicity) shows high mean helium with moderate variability, while compressible wind shows lower mean helium but extreme variability (80-100%). The 90% quantile reaches comparable values in both regimes, revealing compressible wind is a heterogeneous mixture of source types.
